"**I Love It** " is a song by Swedish DJ duo [Icona Pop](/wiki/Icona_Pop
"Icona Pop") featuring vocals from British recording artist [Charli
XCX](/wiki/Charli_XCX "Charli XCX"). It was released in May 2012 as a [digital
download](/wiki/Music_download "Music download") in Sweden, where it peaked at
number two on the singles chart. The song was added to their debut studio
album, _[Icona Pop](/wiki/Icona_Pop_\(album\) "Icona Pop \(album\)")_ , as
well as their EP _Iconic_ and their debut international album, _[This Is...
Icona Pop](/wiki/This_Is..._Icona_Pop "This Is... Icona Pop")_.[1]

The song received positive reviews from music critics, and publications
_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone_\(magazine\) "Rolling Stone
\(magazine\)")_ and [Pitchfork](/wiki/Pitchfork_Media "Pitchfork Media")
included it on their year-end lists for 2012. The song went on to become Icona
Pop and Charli XCX's first US hit, peaking at number seven on the [_Billboard_
Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")[2] and was certified
double-platinum by the [Recording Industry Association of
America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America"), denoting over 2 million copies sold in the United
States. In June 2013, over a year after it was released elsewhere, the song
charted at number 1 on the UK Singles Chart. It has gone on to sell 4.3
million certified downloads.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Love_It_\(Icona_Pop_song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Charli_XCX_%40_Postivus_2013_%289819955206%29.jpg/220px-
Charli_XCX_%40_Postivus_2013_%289819955206%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charli_XCX_@_Postivus_2013_\(9819955206\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charli_XCX_@_Postivus_2013_\(9819955206\).jpg "Enlarge")

Singer Charli XCX co-wrote and recorded an earlier version of "I Love It".

The song was originally written by Charli XCX, whom Icona Pop met several
times in London.[3] Swedish producer [Patrik
Berger](/wiki/Patrik_Berger_\(record_producer\) "Patrik Berger \(record
producer\)") sent Charli two beats, and she quickly wrote songs for each of
them, one of which became "I Love It" and the other of which became her
following single "[You're the One](/wiki/You%27re_the_One_\(Charli_XCX_song\)
"You're the One \(Charli XCX song\)")".[4] However, she later stated that she
knew she would not end up releasing it herself because she could not reconcile
it with her sound.[5]

While recording "Good for You" with Icona Pop, Berger presented them with
Charli's work on "I Love It".[6] Band member Aino Jawo said she felt a
connection to the song because it mirrored her own experiences, and the line
"You're from the 70s but I'm a 90s [bitch](/wiki/Bitch_\(insult\) "Bitch
\(insult\)")" reminded her of an older man she had known.[7] Member Caroline
Hjelt described Charli XCX's original demo as "more cute, in a way…really cool
and cocky".[8] Icona Pop approached Swedish producer [Style of
Eye](/wiki/Style_of_Eye "Style of Eye") to make a rougher version of the
track, telling him, "We want the [punkiness](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock"). We
want the 'fuck it' feeling."[6]

"I Love It" is set in [common
time](/wiki/Time_signature#Notational_variations_in_simple_time "Time
signature") with a tempo of 126 [beats per minute](/wiki/Beats_per_minute
"Beats per minute") (Allegro), and is described as an
[electropop](/wiki/Electropop "Electropop")[9] and [dance-pop](/wiki/Dance-pop
"Dance-pop")[10][11] song. It is written in [A♭ major](/wiki/A%E2%99%AD_major
"A♭ major"), with an [authentic cadence](/wiki/Authentic_cadence "Authentic
cadence") for the main [chord progression](/wiki/Chord_progression "Chord
progression").[12] _[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard
\(magazine\)")_ critic Jessica Hopper defined the instrumental by its "swells
of revving synths" and prominent [sub-bass](/wiki/Sub-bass "Sub-bass")
sounds.[13] Pitchfork writer Lindsay Zoladz commented that the song was
"basically just two-and-a-half minutes of [drop](/wiki/Drop_\(music\) "Drop
\(music\)")";[14] colleague Larry Fitzmaurice noted the track's
[maximalist](/wiki/Maximalist "Maximalist") approach fit the contemporary
trends in electronic and pop music.[15]

The song's lyrics describe breaking up with an older boyfriend. In its chorus,
Icona Pop and Charli XCX shout in unison "I don't care / I love it".[16]
Critics compared the song's breakup narrative to [Kelly
Clarkson](/wiki/Kelly_Clarkson "Kelly Clarkson")'s 2004 single "[Since U Been
Gone](/wiki/Since_U_Been_Gone "Since U Been Gone")",[14][17] and journalist
[Chuck Eddy](/wiki/Chuck_Eddy "Chuck Eddy") wrote in a piece for
_[Spin](/wiki/Spin_\(magazine\) "Spin \(magazine\)")_ that the track's
brattiness was similar to British band [Shampoo](/wiki/Shampoo_\(band\)
"Shampoo \(band\)").[18]

## Release and
promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Love_It_\(Icona_Pop_song\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Release and promotion")]

"I Love It" was released in Sweden in May 2012. It entered the [Swedish
Singles Chart](/wiki/Sverigetopplistan "Sverigetopplistan") the following
month at number 48, and after two months on the chart, the song peaked at
number two for three consecutive weeks.[19] After its January 2013 appearance
on an episode of _[Girls](/wiki/Girls_\(TV_series\) "Girls \(TV series\)")_ ,
the song performed better in digital downloads than it had upon initial
release.[20] Ten days later it entered the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"),[3] eventually climbing to
number seven on the chart.[2] Jawo and Hjelt's first performance with Charli
XCX happened in April 2013, after seeing her back stage at a [South by
Southwest](/wiki/South_by_Southwest "South by Southwest") showcase where both
acts were playing.[21]

In June 2013, several cover versions of the song entered the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"), including one by vlogger
[Venus Angelic](/wiki/Venus_Angelic "Venus Angelic").[22] When Icona Pop
released their version, it entered at the top of the chart, overtaking [Robin
Thicke](/wiki/Robin_Thicke "Robin Thicke")'s "[Blurred
Lines](/wiki/Blurred_Lines "Blurred Lines")" featuring [T.I.](/wiki/T.I.
"T.I.") and [Pharrell Williams](/wiki/Pharrell_Williams "Pharrell
Williams").[23]

## Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Love_It_\(Icona_Pop_song\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

"I Love It" was met with positive reviews from music critics. The song placed
15th on _[The Village Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ 's
2012 [Pazz & Jop](/wiki/Pazz_%26_Jop "Pazz & Jop") list,[24] and it rose to
eighth place the following year.[25] [Pitchfork Media](/wiki/Pitchfork_Media
"Pitchfork Media") labeled it "Best New Music", calling the song "delectable,
empowering, infinitely repeatable".[15] Pitchfork later listed the song number
50 on its "Top 100 Tracks of 2012" list.[17] _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ placed "I Love It" at number 35
on its year-end list, naming it "the Euro-slut club jam of the summer".[26]
Amrit Singh for [Stereogum](/wiki/Stereogum "Stereogum") described it as
"fun",[9] Heather Phares commented Jawo and Hjelt "half-sung, half-shouted
vocals and revved-up synths make the song inescapably catchy".[27] Kat Bein of
the _[Miami New Times](/wiki/Miami_New_Times "Miami New Times")_ called the
song a "[feminist](/wiki/Feminism "Feminism") pop anthem".[28]

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Love_It_\(Icona_Pop_song\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Music video")]

The music video for "I Love It" was directed by Fredrik Etoall. The video was
shot in a day by friends of the band while they were in Paris.[7] It shows
Jawo and Hjelt playing a show for a crowd shouting the lyrics and dancing,
with additional shots from backstage and an after-party.[29] It also includes
outdoor shots of them wearing fringed jackets that they made. Charli XCX does
not appear in the video. [7]

## Cover
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Love_It_\(Icona_Pop_song\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Cover versions")]

Several cover versions have charted in the UK.

Artist  | Peak position  | Reference   
---|---|---  
[Loreen Harris](/wiki/Loreen_Harris "Loreen Harris") | 74  | [95]  
[Venus Angelic](/wiki/Venus_Angelic "Venus Angelic") | 71  | [22]  
Remix Junkies  | 49  | [96]  
Remix Chix  | 61  | [97]  
New Music Masters  | 51  | [98]  
  
In 2017, Swedish singer [Moneybrother](/wiki/Moneybrother "Moneybrother")
released a [punk rock](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock") inspired cover version of
the song as a part of the eighth season of _[Så mycket
bättre](/wiki/S%C3%A5_mycket_b%C3%A4ttre "Så mycket bättre")_. The track
received mixed to positive reviews, ultimately failing to chart.[99][100]
